rsbNotes.title: Lam 3
rsbNotes.text: 3:1–66 As an individual expresses the grief of the community, hope and consolation are sustained by a knowledge of God’s compassionate love.

rsbNotes.title: Lam 3:1
rsbNotes.text: 3:1 I am the man. This chapter is an acrostic with three verses for each letter of the Hebrew alphabet. On the author’s possible identity as Jeremiah, and the acrostic form in Hebrew poetry, see the Introduction, and further below. For portrayals of the Lord Himself as the One who has afflicted the speaker, see Job 19:21; Ps. 88:7, 15; Jer. 15:17, 18. In this poem an individual expresses the grief of his community (vv. 22, 40–47).

rsbNotes.title: Lam 3:2
rsbNotes.text: 3:2 into darkness without any light. Contrast Is. 9:2. Darkness is a metaphor for the distress experienced as the absence of God; light stands for the opposite: salvation and blessing. The day of the Lord is described in these terms at Amos 5:18.

rsbNotes.title: Lam 3:4
rsbNotes.text: 3:4 skin . . . bones. These are pictures of physical distress, perhaps due to age or illness (Job 13:28; Is. 38:13).

rsbNotes.title: Lam 3:5
rsbNotes.text: 3:5 bitterness and tribulation. Emotional and physical effects of distress go hand in hand.

rsbNotes.title: Lam 3:6
rsbNotes.text: 3:6 the dead of long ago. The distresses and diseases of life diminish its fullness, culminating in death. In his weakened condition, the prophet considers himself to have little more participation in life than if he were actually dead. From the perspective of the living, the dead exist not at all, or as shadows (Prov. 2:18; 9:18 and notes). For other pictures of death in the Old Testament, see Job 3:11–19; Ps. 6:5; 115:17; Is. 14:18, 19. Against this background the Old Testament is eloquent in its testimony to resurrection beyond the grave (Job 19:25–27; Ps. 16:9–11; 49:15; 73:24).

rsbNotes.title: Lam 3:8
rsbNotes.text: 3:8 shuts out my prayer. For unheard prayer see Ps. 10:1; 13:1; 22:1, 2.

rsbNotes.title: Lam 3:10–12
rsbNotes.text: 3:10–12 a bear . . . his arrow. Some of the hazards that could actually overtake the traveler are vivid ways of expressing terror and distress.

rsbNotes.title: Lam 3:14
rsbNotes.text: 3:14 the laughingstock. See Jer. 20:7.

rsbNotes.title: Lam 3:17
rsbNotes.text: 3:17 peace . . . happiness. These conditions, the sum of blessing, are totally absent.

rsbNotes.title: Lam 3:18
rsbNotes.text: 3:18 My endurance . . . Lord. The expression of hopelessness in the poem reaches its climax here.

rsbNotes.title: Lam 3:20
rsbNotes.text: 3:20 remembers. The poet’s experience is a symbol of the people’s; see the language in 1:7.

rsbNotes.title: Lam 3:21
rsbNotes.text: 3:21 this I call to mind. Memory that once discouraged now encourages (Ps. 77:3–9, 10–15). The memory of God’s devotion to His people brings hope out of hopelessness.

rsbNotes.title: Lam 3:22–24
rsbNotes.text: 3:22–24 The climactic point of the poem and the book is reached here. The lament form often has turning points where the experience of rejection by God turns unexpectedly to confidence, based on a knowledge of His character and of His past mercies. See the confessions of trust and hope in Ps. 22.

rsbNotes.title: Lam 3:22–23
rsbNotes.text: 3:22, 23 See “God Is Love: Divine Goodness and Faithfulness” at Ps. 136:1.

rsbNotes.title: Lam 3:22
rsbNotes.text:
3:22 steadfast love. On the Hebrew word (h.esed) see Ps. 36:5 note. The plural form, used here, recalls many acts or perhaps the riches of divine love.

mercies. God’s covenant devotion is always joined with His compassion, a term of profound emotion. We are not consumed because God’s compassion is not consumed. God’s wrath toward His people will end because His compassion cannot end (4:22; Hos. 11:8).

rsbNotes.title: Lam 3:23
rsbNotes.text:
3:23 every morning. God’s love will bring the morning of salvation (Ps. 90:14; Mal. 4:2; Luke 1:78).

faithfulness. The unqualified reliability of God makes Him worthy of faith (Hab. 2:4).

rsbNotes.title: Lam 3:24
rsbNotes.text: 3:24 my portion. This phrase recalls the territorial allocations to the Israelite tribes. The priests and Levites, who were landless, had the Lord as their portion (Num. 18:20; cf. Ps. 73:26).

rsbNotes.title: Lam 3:25
rsbNotes.text: 3:25 The Lord . . . seeks him. God is always good to those who seek, hope, and wait for Him (cf. 1 Chr. 28:9). The threefold “good” in this context (cf. vv. 26, 27) focuses on God’s goodness.

rsbNotes.title: Lam 3:27
rsbNotes.text: 3:27 in his youth. The reference is apparently to Jeremiah’s suffering in early and middle life, possibly signifying a relief from it in old age. Perhaps the community, like an individual, should hope for the yoke to be lifted with the passage of time.

rsbNotes.title: Lam 3:28–30
rsbNotes.text:
3:28–30 Let him . . . insults. The prophet exhorts the afflicted to bear present suffering, in the light of the affirmation in the next verses.

sit alone. Cf. 1:1.

rsbNotes.title: Lam 3:30
rsbNotes.text: 3:30 let him give his cheek. The humiliation of Israel foreshadows Christ’s humiliation (Is. 50:6; Matt. 26:67).

rsbNotes.title: Lam 3:31–33
rsbNotes.text: 3:31–33 Since God is compassionate, the present experience of His wrath must be short-lived (Ps. 30:5; Is. 54:7; Hos. 6:1). Again, compassion is joined to God’s unfailing love (Hebrew h.esed, 3:22). God does not afflict men “willingly,” that is, “cheerfully,” or “from His heart” even in judgment.

rsbNotes.title: Lam 3:34–36
rsbNotes.text: 3:34–36 The implication of these verses is that God cannot approve such things (Job 8:3). Of course, God has approved these very things, since He has brought them to pass. This is the problem of judgment and affliction that the poet faces.

rsbNotes.title: Lam 3:37–38
rsbNotes.text: 3:37, 38 All that happens is by God’s word (Gen. 1:3), calamity as well as good (Amos 3:6).

rsbNotes.title: Lam 3:39
rsbNotes.text:
3:39 Since all things take place by the word of the Lord, no living man can complain when God brings calamity as punishment for sin.

the punishment of his sins. The sin of the people is an important part of the prophet’s answer to the problem of judgment and affliction (dreadful though God’s judgment is, 2:20–22). The phrase in Hebrew implies that sin and consequent punishment belong inescapably together.

rsbNotes.title: Lam 3:40–47
rsbNotes.text: 3:40–47 Notice that the speaker is plural throughout this section.

rsbNotes.title: Lam 3:40–42
rsbNotes.text: 3:40–42 Let us test . . . transgressed. This is a call to repentance, acknowledging sin. The impulse to confess sins seems to give way soon to renewed lamentation, following the statement, “you have not forgiven” (v. 42). The confession could have been superficial or hypocritical. In any case the penalties were not lifted.

rsbNotes.title: Lam 3:43–45
rsbNotes.text: 3:43–45 You have wrapped . . . among the peoples. Here the prophet parodies the actions of God at the Exodus. Then God’s anger helped Israel; it was their enemies who were slain without pity; and the cloud was a sign of favor. Israel was precious among the nations, not “scum and garbage.”

rsbNotes.title: Lam 3:48–66
rsbNotes.text: 3:48–66 The speech now reverts to the singular again.

rsbNotes.title: Lam 3:48
rsbNotes.text: 3:48 rivers of tears. There are strong echoes of Jeremiah in this close association between the people’s grief and the poet’s grief. A link is suggested between the suffering of the people and of the poet.

rsbNotes.title: Lam 3:49
rsbNotes.text: 3:49 My eyes will flow. These words reflect familiar lament language (Ps. 6:6; 42:3; Jer. 9:1; 18).

rsbNotes.title: Lam 3:52
rsbNotes.text: 3:52 enemies without cause. Ps. 35:19; John 15:25.

rsbNotes.title: Lam 3:53
rsbNotes.text: 3:53 into the pit. Ps. 28:1; 88:6. The life of Jeremiah may be in view again in these verses (Jer. 38:6).

rsbNotes.title: Lam 3:55
rsbNotes.text: 3:55 I called . . . pit. See Ps. 16:10, 11; 30:1; and the experience of Jonah (Jon. 2:2–7). Christ’s suffering as the righteous Servant of the Lord brings this recurring theme of the suffering prophets and their rescue by the Lord to its highest fulfillment.

rsbNotes.title: Lam 3:56
rsbNotes.text: 3:56 you heard my plea. The turning point of the lament arrives when the poet is reassured that the Lord has heard his prayer (Ps. 6:8–10).

rsbNotes.title: Lam 3:57
rsbNotes.text: 3:57 Do not fear. This is a common exhortation in Isaiah (e.g., Is. 41:10; cf. Mark 6:50).

rsbNotes.title: Lam 3:58–66
rsbNotes.text: 3:58–66 This section takes up the biblical theme of innocent, vicarious suffering that reaches its consummation in Christ’s death for those who brought it upon Him.

rsbNotes.title: Lam 3:58–60
rsbNotes.text: 3:58–60 my cause . . . redeemed my life . . . my cause. In Jer. 50:34 the Lord is the Redeemer of Judah and pleads their case. Here the Lord pleads against them, because they have turned against His prophet.

rsbNotes.title: Lam 3:64–66
rsbNotes.text: 3:64–66 repay them. The note of revenge is present in Jer. 12:1, as in Ps. 77:6, 7.
